title: What did the Ancient Greeks think about transgender people? - Quora

response.answer_text: What did the Ancient Greeks think about transgender people? Because of the very strict gender roles in ancient Greece a transgender person would probably been regarded with horror—a trans man would have be seen as not “staying in ‘her’ place” while a trans woman would arouse ire for “acting like a woman.” Keep in mind an adult male who was the receptive partner in sex could be punished legally. That being said the idea of changing gender or gender roles was not totally unheard of in certain religious aspects. The god Dionysos was called androgynos or “androgynous,” as well as gynnis “womanish” and he was considered a god of people who cross-dressed. There were stories that those caught up in the frenzy of his worship would cross gender-boundaries as far as behavior. There is the story of Herakles being enslaved by a Queen who made him dress in women’s clothing and spin and weave while she wore his tunic and carried his club. In later Roman times there was the cult of Attis where the priests would dress in women's clothing and sometimes were even ritually castrated. The Romans were both upset with that cult, and the cult Dionysos/Bacchus. Finally there was the story of the seer who lived (magically) as both a man and a woman.
